text: A tough slog in the beginning, with talks of territory wars, and a sideline story which felt very disconnected. Eventually, the characters developed, the intrigue built and I was hooked. A real page turner for the second half. Recommend.
I may have been too young to grasp it when I read it, or perhaps I just had too high expectations for it

This book was comprised of two very different reading experiences for me. The first half was unenjoyable. I was utterly lost and had to continually scan the beginning pages to figure out what Melina was referring to. It took alot of self control not to stop reading and go onto something else. Then the second half of the book happened. Finally I understood what was going on and began to enjoy the novel. I just wish things were a bit clearer in the beginning.
I had a bit of trouble getting into this book at first but once I dived in!! Let me tell you I could not stop falling in love with the characters, especially Griggs!
3.5?griggs å taylors relationship😗🤌

This book was heart wrenching. It also tried way too hard to throw plot twists at you, so it made everything vague and hard to follow so that it could surprise you. It was beautifully written and was very compelling, clearly because I couldn't put it down.

This book was a hard read. It took me about 200 pages to get into, and I barely understood what was going on plot wise until then. There's so little description of scenery and even characters, that at times it felt like I was reading a script for a film. However, I did like the characters, found the story interesting enough, and I cried at the end. I'm also cutting it some slack as I started a new job almost at the time I started reading it, and I was so exhausted for the first few weeks, that I barely had the energy to read, let alone understand a kind of complicated narrative. So that's why I'm giving it three stars instead of two.

Jag läser Jellicoe Road 9 år efter att den kom ut och blev oerhört hypad. Jag är tyvärr inte lika tagen. Första halvan är rörig med hopp i tid och mellan dröm och verklighet. Det tar sig och jag förstår alltmer av pusslet, vilket är både förfärande och rörande. Min samlade känsla är ändå att jag aldrig kommer karaktärerna in på livet. När jag börjar om med första kapitlet förstår jag dock saker på ett helt annat vis (såklart) och jag tror att det kanske är nyckeln: läs Jellicoe Road flera gånger!
review to come...

Wow, this book was all kinds of confusing! Too many plot lines going on, so I was really lost in the beginning. Things came together in the end, but I literally had to write down who was related to who, just to keep my head from spinning. Sad, depressing, heartbreaking…it was ok, but just wasn’t my cup of tea. (Also, why do such terrible things always happen at/near boarding schools?? Sending my kids to one would be a big NOPE. 😂)
I think I would give this a 3.5 maybe a 4
Que enredo, Chica problemática y caos por donde no lo había.

3.5 stars. I thought the characters were interesting, and the coming-of-age / mystery / romance / family drama mashup worked for me, but I just found it hard to get into this book. I’d say by the second half / last third I was fully engrossed but until then it was slow going.

I can’t really describe it but this book just has this “Australia-atmosphere“ to it. Ever since I lived in Australia for a while I’ve had this longing for a childhood living there and reading this book now made me a little sad because of that.The beginning was a little confusing to me and I didn’t really get what was going on for the first three or four chapters.Overall it was a good read but I didn’t enjoy it as much as I enjoyed “Looking for Alibrandi“.

To be honest, I think I read this book to quickly. I felt like I was always missing something while reading this text, and I'm not sure I necessarily want to re-read it to find out what I missed because it seemed just sad.
3.5 stars

i'm putting a placeholder rating here of 3 stars but i may change it. This book is truly a challenge for me to rate. it clocks in at about 420 pages, and the first 300 pages were...not great for me. it took a little bit for me to settle into the story and understand what was going on. i kept feeling unsure if this was some kind of magical realism, since there seemed to be this group of kids at a school mostly devoid of adults or any actual learning. then, once i finally felt oriented to the setting, i felt bored. like, really bored. up until about the last 125 pages or so, where suddenly the story became lovely and engaging and heartbreaking. if the entire book had been like the last 100 pages, i would have been debating a 4-5 star rating. but the first 300 pages were 2 stars at best. i'm still not even sure if i would recommend this one? i just don't know.

”Jag minns kärlek. Det är det jag hela tiden måste komma ihåg. Det är konstigt hur man kan glömma allting utom att det fanns personer som älskade en. Kanske är det därför människor har så svårt att komma över sina kärlekshistorier. Det är inte smärtan de ska lägga bakom sig, det är kärleken.”

First, I listened to the Audible version. I don't recommend it. From reading other reviews, I'm not alone in this thinking. This story is SUPER confusing and requires your undivided attention. I had to start it over after reading reviews that told me there were TWO stories being told at the same time. I totally didn't get that in the audiobook.I think I like the premise, but there are things about it that I just thought were pointless-like the territory wars. I still don't understand how that had any bearing on the actual story. It seemed kind of pointless and added to the confusion. The first half of the book is incredibly confusing. When the big reveals comes out half way through, your head starts to get unmuffled, but why do you have to go through half a book of confusion to get there?Not my favorite book.
hehehehe.... hihihihi.... joonaaaah 😘😘😘
2,75Es un libro bastante random la verdad. Entretenido pero sin más.

3.5 stars - Fine, this book was pretty great. It was so hard at first getting into (probably cause I read it for school with a due date in my head) Had some pretty cute romance, but in the end I’d say It was just another one that was just not it for me!

3.5 StarsThis was a cute little read, albeit a little too middle-grades for me. The writing and plot are both pretty simplistic, which is what keeps this from being 4 or 5 stars. But it’s a good found-family story with a bittersweet ending. I could see my daughter falling in love with this book, maybe when she’s 9 or 10 years old.

“So why would I want someone to be my everything when one day that might not be around? What will be left of me then?”“¿Para qué querría que alguien fuera mi “todo” si un día tal vez ya no estará a mi lado? ¿Qué quedaría de mi entonces?”Me tiré a la piscina con esta lectura porque era el primer libro elegido por el grupo creado por @natinbooks para el reto #unlibroeninglesalmes que organiza este año. No tenía ni idea de qué iba la historia y lo cierto es que me pasé las primeras casi 100 páginas más perdida que un pulpo en un garaje, porque la narración alterna dos líneas temporales (el presente y el pasado en forma de un relato inconexo y desordenado que ha escrito una de los personajes) y cuesta un montón entender lo que pasó/está pasando.Básicamente tenemos un cóctel conformado por un grupo de adolescentes y niños que viven en una especie de internado, los chicos del pueblo cercano y un grupo de “cadetes juveniles” que pasan el verano en un campamento “¿pseudomilitar?” en los terrenos anexos al internado. Hay un juego como de bandas, en el que pelean entre ellos por el territorio. Desaparece una persona. Reaparecen viejos conocidos de los protagonistas… en fin, una historia de adolescentes extraña.Me obligué a proseguir con la lectura y acabarlo y la verdad es que al final va mejorando un poco, porque empiezas a entender cosas, la narración se ordena, se hace más ligera y los protagonistas interactúan más entre ellos. Y conseguí engancharme en las últimas 100 páginas, en las que me eché unas risas y la historia se hizo más interesante, aunque muy previsible.¿Lo recomendaría? Mmmmm, creo que no, salvo que no tengáis nada más que leer alrededor o que necesitéis una lectura ligera de las de no pensar.

No sé ni como empezar a escribir mi opinión sobre este libro. Me ha dejado muy reflexiva. Empezaré diciendo que desde el principio he ido con unas expectativas altísimas y eso ha sido un problema. Me ha costado entender la historia, ya que es muy dispersa. Me he liado mucho con los personajes, no sabía si los nombres eran de chicos o de chicas, quien era el narrador... en fin, me he hecho un lío hasta más o menos las últimas 100 páginas, que ha sido cuando he empezado a entender cosas relevantes de la trama y me ha empezado a interesar. Hay escenas realmente fuertes, emocionantes, sentimentales y que me han conmovido, pero en general, me he quedado con un sabor de boca algo insípido. Es como si me hubieran faltado cosas por entender. Necesito más tiempo para digerirlo todo o una relectura en un futuro próximo. En resumen: gran parte del libro ha sido un poco meh pero la parte final me ha gustado y engamchado muchísimo. 3/5⭐
Al principio de me enganchaba nada, pero conforme vas leyendo todo va cobrando sentido y tiene un final muy bonito

I felt a lot of feelings while reading this, but one of the primary ones was exasperation. Jellicoe Road is insanely sentimental, and if you don't have a stomach for that kind of thing, this is a tough hang. It is the most YA book of all time, and I mean that in a lot of the good ways and all of the annoying ways that implies. It's not an exaggeration to say the main character has an emotional breakdown every five pages. The number of tears shed in this book could power a water park or keep a family alive in the desert. I'm all for tears, but when every moment is given equal hurricane-esque emotional weight, it's hard to take them as seriously. (Then again, that's basically what it's like to be in high school, so it's not like it's inaccurate.)The ending is really strong, and I think the afterglow skews the ratings a bit, because the rest of the book is less so. Then again, I am not 14 years old, and this book isn't for me :) So I should probably stop talking. If nothing else, this book is genuine and deeply felt.

The premise of the three adolescent groups struggling to survive despite an underlying darkness of abandonment and tragedy reminded me of 'Lord of the Flies'. Marchetta is a fine writer with introspective characterisation, but at times it was difficult to follow why the characters from the three groups were so obsessed with their territorial rights and rules. Then a scene is described very effectively and Marchetta's writing skill is evident. Her experience teaching in a boarding school is also evident. But the heirarchies seemed pointless. Maybe that is the point?

“i remember the tremble in my mother’s body when the midwife first placed me in her arms. i remember the feeling of slipping between those fingers. it’s like she never really managed to grab hold of me with a firmness that spoke of never letting go. it’s like she never got it right.” “it’s funny how you can forget everything except people loving you.” “want to believe in something. but love the world just the way it is.”

3,5 ⭐Esta historia me ha mantenido súper enganchada todo el rato y me ha encantado desde el principio, como vas descubriendo detalles de ella poco a poco hasta que todo se desvela. Es una historia desgarradora que me tenía todo en rato una sensación de tristeza que no se si me gusta o no. Pero en general muy muy bonita.

What a wild ride! This is the coming of age story of Taylor Markham, an Australian teen who was abandoned at 11. Now at boarding school, she is piecing together the pages of her past (view spoiler)[(literally, as the young woman who serves as a kind of mentor to her has been writing a manuscript/journal/memoir) (hide spoiler)]. With mystery, romance, and teen drama, this would be a good recommendation for fans of popular books from the same era (i.e. Twilight, Looking for Alaska, Just Listen, Crank, or Thirteen Reasons Why).

This book was certainly not bad and by the end I actually really liked where it ended up and had developed a fondness for pretty much all the characters by the time we got there. But the journey it took to get there was just so needlessly convoluted. I just felt the construction of this story didn't work for me. It's like it was doing everything possible to confuse me by constantly flitting between present and dreams and Hannah's story, but I don't feel like it actually added anything to the overall story by doing that. Like I still guessed all the revelations and it didn't make it more impactful by confusing me the entire time, I feel like if it was told in a less random time-jump way I could've felt these moments a lot more. There's these great emotional beats at the end that honestly didn't hit me the way I knew they should have because it took so long to get to it. Also the beginning plot of their 'house wars' or whatever was as dumb as it sounded and legit led nowhere. It felt like such ridiculous forced conflict and wasn't even well explained enough for me to care. It took itself far too seriously and I found myself eye-rolling for a lot of it and waiting for the real meat of the story to happen. I also found the main relationship and Taylor herself super grating. All of their decisions are beyond frustrating and I know they're teenagers and I know they need to grow in their arc, but I didn't really find myself routing for them for most of the book. By the end I enjoyed them enough separately that I was like, 'ok sure, fine' but again didn't hit me the way I felt it should've. Overall this book was just super weird. It's certainly different and I'm all for fresh ideas, but it just didn't do it for me at all. Not my fav, but I can see why others may have enjoyed it more.

It took me days to finish this book. Why? Normally, a 290-page book takes me 3-5 hours to finish, but this book? Let's just say it needs a lot of time to digest. I've been meaning to read this book for ages but I always felt that I'm not ready for it...and up to this point (even after mincing it word by word), I still feel that I wasn't. Maybe I should've waited 'til I'm ready for this roller coaster ride. For those of you who loves a great drama unfolding right before you, then this is your book! Not giving out any details of the plot as it would be best to enter this hole blinded.

i mean, it was fine, i guess, there's some good lines, some complex relationships - i like the characters. i've been reading a lot of reviews in hopes of better understanding why people love this book so much, and all i've concluded is that i will never understand. a lot of the reasons people have for not enjoying this book are very dumb or downright factually incorrect. all of the five star reviews just gush about the story without mentioning WHAT or WHY they liked it.
Secretos, drama y amor.Me encanta que la historia se desarrolle en Australia.
Demasiado drama al final, creo que con un poquito menos me hubiera gustado más la historia, al final se unen todos los cabos, igual me gustó

3.5 – This was a book I wish I had the patience to read as an attentively challenged younger teenager. I couldn’t really appreciate much of what went on in the earlier chapters as a twenty-year-old but it’s the kind of storytelling that would have compelled me to write more nuance to my material at that age instead of going stagnant in my later teens.Marchetta offered little distinctions to set out a clearer picture of the grounds or the characters but I take it down as personal style and it’s not like it worked against her. The focus she set upon literary devices such as a Chekhov’s Gun was pronounced enough for younger readers to appreciate without making it unnecessarily complex. The text was haunting and wistful. It’s not the kind that would have made it difficult for me to put down but if I do, I’d somehow regret it because the story is littered with bits and pieces that are easily relevant to the plot later. I did get a little annoyed at some points when something is mentioned or introduced and the reader was expected to just take that in as it is despite how slightly important it is to remember it later in the story. It was a good piece. Yet I personally didn’t appreciate how the intentionally dispersed excerpts muddled the story in a way that hindered it rather than stylise or emphasise the plot.
